input:
Title: Instant fallback fix for aarch64

Description: # Objective The current `Instant` fallback implementation in `bevy_platform` contains a bug on ARM CPUs, such as Apple Silicon. It appears only under specific conditions — when the `std` feature is **disabled** for desktop builds on ARM. For web builds, as I can see, the time implementation differs and does not exhibit this issue. Still, this remains a bug. In the current implementation, the code reads the system counter value (tick count) and incorrectly interprets it as nanoseconds. We have to additionally divide number by [frequency](https://developer.arm.com/documentation/ddi0601/2020-12/AArch64-Registers/CNTFRQ-EL0--Counter-timer-Frequency-register) to obtain elapsed time. ## Solution Query the system counter frequency and compute nanoseconds using the correct formula: ``` // number o
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Instant fallback fix for aarch64

Title: increaese influencers per vertex on a skinned mesh

Description: ## Bevy version and features - The release number or commit hash of the version you're using. - If you're not using default features, the combination of bevy's cargo features you are using. ## What you did tried to load a skinned gltf mesh with an animation. ## What went wrong loads of vertexes stuck on (0,0,0) ## Additional information works fine in houdini. ai told me • I inspected your char.gltf and found the culprit: the mesh uses 3 joint/weight attribute sets (JOINTS_0/1/2 and WEIGHTS_0/1/2), which means up to 12 influences per vertex. Bevy 0.14 only supports 2 sets (8 influences). The third set is ignored, leaving some vertices with effectively zero skinning weights, so they collapse to (0,0,0) during animation. maybe the error is something else but it seems like a probably explanati

Severity: medium
Component: save
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: increaese influencers per vertex on a skinned mesh

Title: Allow arbitrary areas for `core.generate_decorations`

Description: ### Problem The function `core.generate_decorations` no longer allows rectangular areas (XZ plane) and if you try to generate decorations in a rectangle anyway, Luanti errors out. Only squares on the XZ plane are allowed right now. This restriction is annoying as it makes it writing custom mapgens that need decorations more difficult, as you have to awkwardly work around that restriction. ### Solutions Allow rectangle areas for this function again. ### Alternatives Idk. ### Additional context Rectangular areas were allowed up until 5.13.0 (and dev versions). As far I remember, this restriction was added as a safety precaution but I wonder if the code can be rewritten to support rectangular decoration areas again without being a problem for safety.
output:

Summary: Allow arbitrary areas for `core.generate_decorations`

input:
Title: Consider autogenerating bindings (and/or serde)

Description: ### Problem We currently write bindings by hand using the stack-based Lua API, with a bunch of helper functions. This is verbose, somewhat error prone, results in inconsistencies, and more work than it needs to be. The same applies to serialization and deserialization. Arguably added constraints (like backwards compatibility) may make custom solutions more appealing, but especially for SSCSM that won't be a problem, so all serde code there is just braindead recursive "(de)serialize this thing". The ideal point would be that you can (roughly) just supply the signature of an API function and all the rest is autogenerated (for SSM: conversion of parameters from Lua to C, conversion of return values from C to Lua; vice versa for a callback; for SSCSM, serde code would ideally also be autogener
output:

Component: other
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Consider autogenerating bindings (and/or serde)

Title: Remove hardcoded color of infobox in /help

Description: This PR removes the hardcoded box color in the `/help` window behind the textarea that describes the selected command. It also slightly shrinks the textarea. ## Why? The short version is: Flexibility. Because it makes it easier to specify game styles without having to work around builtin limitations. The long version is: IMO builtin formspecs like the `/help` dialog should be stylable as much as possible and respect the game's `set_formspec_prepend` options. Hardcoding any color makes styling them harder as it restricts the amount of possible font colors or formspec colors you can use by default. Currently, this forces game authors to only use bright font colors for text areas, because dark font colors make the text hard to read on the forced dark background in `/help`. My simple solution
output:

Summary: Remove hardcoded color of infobox in /help

Title: Use <filesystem>?

Description: ### Summary Our `fs::*` helpers (`filesys.h`) have some deficits: * There are missing features, e.g. it's not easy to decomposition paths. * They might be buggy. I.e. windows C: thing is not supported, afaik. * Imo they're somewhat confusing (e.g. several functions that sound like they give you an absolute path, and the documentation is confusing). * It's platform-dependent code that we have to maintain. ### Suggestion * Allow to use C++17's filesystem std lib subsystem (`<filesystem>`) in new code. * Replace old code using `fs::*` with an `std::filesystem::*` implementation. ### New dependency ok? TL,DR: yes Context: When switching to C++17, `<filesystem>` wasn't everywhere available yet, IIRC. Applying our [policy for new stuff](https://github.com/luanti-org/luanti/blob/master/doc/develo
output:

Summary: Use <filesystem>?

input:
Title: If the master server vanishes make sure to register again, cleanup

Description: The code never did account for this case that after the registration it might fail to send the heartbeat and just assumed it is still registered. This now ensures that when a heartbeat fails it goes back to unregistered state and tries to register again in 2 minutes, this will be helpful when we want to do master server updates and not forcing people to restart. Also I did some refactoring around that async wrapper, it is now actually using std::async which returns a future object that we can wait on, if the advertister object is destroyed and it had still an ongoing request it would crash, I need to update some other code using this eventually, for now it's just this part.
output:

Summary: If the master server vanishes make sure to register again, cleanup

Title: Fix corner case when unknown node ids run out

Description: The name(/nodedef)-id-mapping we use is essentially just a string pool. Unknown nodes are also internalized. If we run out of ids (which can only happen if there are > circa 2^15 unknown nodes in the world (or by using lbms with not registered nodes (or if someone uses `register_node` with `pcall`))), this breaks. This PR properly handles this corner case. In master, `NodeDefManager::allocateId()` simply doesn't terminate, fixed. `MapBlock::correctBlockNodeIds()` has code to ignore if we run out of ids, and just use the local ids (the ids used in the serialized block). (Note that this code was never executed, as `NodeDefManager::allocateId()` did not return.) This is very wrong, as this means the unknown nodes are just converted into (pretty much arbitrary) different nodes. There is also `
output:
Severity: critical
Component: network
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: Fix corner case when unknown node ids run out

Title: `bevy_reflect::Set::remove` has incorrect documentation

Description: `bevy_reflect::Set::remove` contains [incorrect documentation about the return type](https://docs.rs/bevy_reflect/0.18.0/bevy_reflect/trait.Set.html#tymethod.remove): > If the set did not have this value present, true is returned. If the set did have this value present, false is returned. This contradicts [`std`'s `HashSet`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/collections/struct.HashSet.html#method.remove): > Returns whether the value was present in the set. And the [implementation of `DynamicSet`](https://docs.rs/bevy_reflect/latest/src/bevy_reflect/set.rs.html#242-247): ```rs fn remove(&mut self, value: &dyn PartialReflect) -> bool { self.hash_table .find_entry(Self::internal_hash(value), Self::internal_eq(value)) .map(HashTableOccupiedEntry::remove) .is_ok() } ``` This is almost certainly a c
output:
Severity: low

Title: Fix joystick button toggle actions repeating indefinitely

Description: ## Summary Fix joystick button toggle actions repeating indefinitely When a joystick button was pressed, toggle actions (like minimap, camera mode) would repeat continuously instead of triggering once. The issue was that `m_keys_pressed[i]` was set to true when a button was pressed, but was never reset to false when the button state remained unchanged or was released. This caused toggle actions to be re-triggered every frame. Now properly reset `m_keys_pressed[i]` to false when the button is not in a "just pressed" state, ensuring toggle actions only fire once per button press. ## Details **Goal:** Fix joystick toggle button behavior to match keyboard behavior (single activation per press) **How it works:** - Added `else` branch to reset `m_keys_pressed[i] = false` when button is not in "j
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: rare
Summary: Fix joystick button toggle actions repeating indefinitely

Title: Rename `Aabb2d`/`Aabb3d` to `BoundingRectangle`/`BoundingBox`

Description: # Objective Fixes the naming inconsistency between bounding volume types in Bevy's math API. Currently we have: - 2D: `BoundingCircle` (descriptive geometric name) vs `Aabb2d` (technical acronym) - 3D: `BoundingSphere` (descriptive geometric name) vs `Aabb3d` (technical acronym) This inconsistency was noted in the original discussion in #10570, where it was acknowledged that "bounding rectangle" would be more intuitive than "aabb2d", but consistency between 2D and 3D was prioritized at the time using the AABB naming convention. **Note**: I recognize this is a matter of API design preference and may not align with everyone's vision. Title: Convert the bottom VCS dock to a `EditorDock` and tie it with the Commit dock

Description: This PR tackles the same objective as #113454 but from another approach: it makes so that the bottom dock follows the Commit dock's state instead of being its own thing. That means that it can't be closed directly, but closes if the Commit dock is closed. Some other changes were necessary: - Add the `is_floating()` method, that simply returns if the dock is in a separate window. - Add the `opened` signal, which is fired when the dock is enabled via the "Editor > Editor Docks" menu. This PR also fixes some bugs: - When the connection to the VCS is disabled and then re-enabled, only the bottom dock would re-appear. - The colors wouldn't update when switching themes. - No scroll hints were added.

Title: Update to cosmic-text 0.15

Description: # Objective Update `bevy_text`'s cosmic-text dependency to 0.15 Fixes #21766 ## Solution Very minimal changes here, nothing user facing except an error return type. * Cosmic-text no longer uses `ttf_parser`, so, to validate fonts during asset loading, a `skrifa::FontRef` is constructed instead. If the font is invalid, the font asset loader now returns a `skrifa::ReadError`, not a `ttf_parser::FaceParsingError`. * To get a font from the global `CosmicFontSystem` instance, the `get_font` function requires a weight now. The weight is looked up from the `CosmicFontSystems` font database, immediately before the `get_font` call. The changes here are a little hackish, but that's a symptom of our lack of support for font collections.

Title: `code.hash_node_position` is not *not* a hash function

Description: (Luanti version: 5.15.0) ### The problem The documentation `lua_api.md` claims that `core.hash_node_function` is not a hash function: > * `core.hash_node_position(pos)`: returns a 48-bit integer > * `pos`: table {x=number, y=number, z=number}, > * Gives a unique numeric encoding for a node position (16+16+16=48bit) > * Despite the name, this is not a hash function (so it doesn't mix or produce collisions). The last line is false. This function maps one distinct set of values (positions using s16 integers) to another distinct set of values (integers from 0 to 2^48-1). This function is frequently used to compute numbers that you can easily store into tables for later lookup. This is a hash function in my book. Just because it doesn't collide or "mix" results doesn't mean it's not a hash func

Severity: low
Component: audio
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: `code.hash_node_position` is not *not* a hash function

Title: Avoid reading the entire asset into memory during asset processing.

Description: # Objective - When processing assets, we first read the whole asset into memory, then process the asset from that in-memory representation. This means that large assets may just not fit into memory causing much bigger issues (e.g., switching over to slow virtual memory). ## Solution - Read the asset twice during processing: 1) once to determine the asset hash, 2) once to actually process the asset. This means the processing code itself doesn't need to read the whole asset into memory at any point, meaning we can now process much bigger assets. However, there are some risks. Asset sources which can't read chunks of an asset - which need to read the whole asset into memory anyway - now have to do so twice (not at the same time though). An example of this kind of asset source is the default W
output:
Severity: medium
Component: performance
Reproducibility: rare
Summary: Avoid reading the entire asset into memory during asset processing.

Title: Fix inconsistent SSR blurriness on rough surfaces.

Description: ### Description The existing implementation of SSR has a subtle visual artifact: reflections on rough surfaces have inconsistent look at different distances. Specifically, they become more glossy as the camera moves away. This PR fixed this issue with minor code changes and performance hit (literally just an additional `+ 1.0` in the shader). The comparison between existing implementation and this PR looks like this: ![ssr_enhancement](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e93bd202-2459-4015-b9c2-81593fdcdb55) ### Explanation The problem of existing implementation is that it computes the mip level as `log2(/*screen_space_blur_amout*/)`, but mip level is, strictly speaking, logarithmic to the diameter of sampling region in the texture. When the blur amount is 0, this value should be 1
output:
Severity: low
Component: graphics
Reproducibility: always
Summary: Fix inconsistent SSR blurriness on rough surfaces.

Title: OpenXR: Don't add frame synthesis as projection views extension unless enabled

Description: On https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/114697, it was discovered that `OpenXRFrameSynthesisExtension` was _always_ registering itself as a projection views extension, even if it wasn't enabled However, the whole reason we have a separate registration for projection views extensions, is that we loop over them in a hot path. So, we want to have as few of them registered as possible This PR makes it so that `OpenXRFrameSynthesisExtension` will only be registered as a projection views extension if it's enabled I tested frame synthesis on the Pico 4 Ultra with this PR, and everything still worked!
output:
Severity: medium

Title: Fix immediate nested loaded assets not loading their dependencies.

Description: # Objective - Previously if you loaded an immediate nested asset, it would **not** load any of its dependencies. This means that you could have handles in your asset that would never load. - Fixes #20988 ## Solution - Propagate loading dependencies to immediate asset loads. - I also deduped some test App setup code. ## Testing - Added a test. One case that does have a slightly undesirable effect is when you immediately-load an asset, take some data from it (but no dependency handles), and then drop the immediately-loaded asset. This change will now also initiate a dependency load, even though we won't use it. However, A) it is much more surprising to have a handle that will never be loaded, B) we should end up cancelling the dependency load once we drop the handle, so we shouldn't pay too

Summary: Fix immediate nested loaded assets not loading their dependencies.

Title: Builtin: Convert TR files to gettext PO

Description: This PR converts the TR locale files in builtin to gettext PO to make them easier to work with in the future. ## How the files were converted The conversion was automated using the Luanti Translation Tools <https://codeberg.org/Wuzzy/Luanti_Translation_Tools>, using a two-step process: 1. Update TR files with `ltt_update.py` (to start with a consistent base; many TR files only had 2 strings, also a new string arrived: "`DM sent to @1: @2`") 2. Convert files with `ltt_convert.py` (0.2.1) All `*.tr` files and `template.txt` are deleted, in favor of `*.po` files and the `*.pot` file. Yes, changing the file format was literally enough, no code needs to be touched. :-) ## How to test 1. Start Luanti in any langauge that builtin supports 2. Test the game if the translation of builtin stuff works

Description: * Feature: Use the builtin profiler to automatically make zones for mod callback functions. * This is useful for modders and other users to find out which parts of which mods are responsible for lag spikes, or for making the server start slow. * (No 100% coverage. If a part of AsyncRunStep is not taken up by a mod callback, it's either (1) the engine doing things (this can also be caused by a mod, if it gave the engine much work to do), (2) the engine waiting on something (e.g. env lock), or (3) a mod callback not recognized by the builtin profiler. Title: Reword g2 error message to be more clear to users

Description: The G2 error was implemented to help users understand why their graphics were going haywire. Unfortunately it still leaves people mystified and we get comments asking what it means. On discord there has been some discussion as to how to rework the error to be more user-friendly. GOALS: - Users understand what to do to fix the error - Error is translated into the user's language The specific issue is that g2 and the language files are tied to the game version (and to a lesser extent, objects, but those very rarely have breaking changes like g2 and language) The reason the g2 is outdated is 99% because people download the portable version and copy only the exe and leave everything else. If the language file is outdated, then one string will be (undefined string) and the rest of the game play

Description: The first commit fixes #16828 The second commit replaces all stack emptiness checks I found, which relied on `name == ""`. I don't see another way how the issue could be fixed, if we allow people to use the `""` item as an itemstack. Alternatively, we could document that `""` can't exist as an itemstack object, and thus can't have item stack meta. (but it currently can by using `set_count(1)` on an empty itemstack). `stack:set_name("")` does still empty the stack, to not break compatibility, but it is not documented I think. ## To do Work in progress - [ ] Wait for some response to see if this solution makes sense and - [ ] then add documentation for how the `""` can/cannot be used as an itemstack. - [ ] Fix crafting ## How to test ```lua local inv = player:get_inventory() local stack = It

instruction: Classify this bug report and provide a structured analysis.
input:
Title: [no squash] Use `int` for handling texture layer index in shader

Description: why so complicated? To use `int` we have to declare the variable `flat`, which is not available on old GLSL (hence the ifdef). Fortunately this doesn't conflict, because all versions that have array textures also have `flat`. Next the driver throws an error at us because you can't use `flat` with the deprecated `varying` (hence doing it only for GLES first). I thought this required migrating to GLSL 3.x, but actually `in`/`out` are already in GLSL 1.5. So that can be fixed. Finally, we can apply that to both GL3 and GLES2 as originally intended. Also we can change the vertex attribute to avoid another potentially problematic float conversion. This *should* fix the "wrong texture rendered" reports we've seen. At least it fixes all bug causes I can think of. references: * https://stackoverfl
output:
Severity: medium
Component: ui
Reproducibility: sometimes
Summary: [no squash] Use `int` for handling texture layer index in shader

Title: Fix audio crackling

Description: For me, this solved the problem when resampling a 48 kHz OGG to 22.05 kHz, or a 22.05 kHz file to 48 kHz. It seems that the length was getting truncated by rounding errors. I removed _everything_ from this PR except the fix, as it seems that people were getting distracted by the sample rate change. Here is a test file. You can test as follows: 1. Add the object to a park 2. Add it to a Merry-go-round and play. 3. Observe there is crackling on `develop`, but not on this branch.
